content.title: Peripheral Arterial Embolism
content.definition: Acute arterial occlusion caused by embolic material (usually thrombus) originating from a proximal source (heart or aorta) lodging at an arterial bifurcation, causing sudden limb ischemia. Most common cause of acute limb ischemia, distinct from thrombosis of atherosclerotic disease.

key_concepts.description: Cardiac (80%): atrial fibrillation (most common), MI with LV thrombus, valvular disease, prosthetic valves, endocarditis, paradoxical embolism through PFO. Arterial (20%): aortic aneurysm, atheroma, ulcerated plaque
Embolism: sudden onset (seconds to minutes), no prior claudication, normal contralateral pulses, cardiac source. Thrombosis: often prior claudication history, diffuse atherosclerosis, gradual onset
Lodges at bifurcations where vessel narrows: aortic bifurcation (saddle embolus), femoral bifurcation (most common - 35-50%), popliteal, brachial
Pain (acute, severe), Pallor, Pulselessness, Poikilothermia (cold), Paresthesias, Paralysis (late sign = muscle death). Paralysis and pain on passive stretch indicate muscle ischemia

Rutherford: Class I = viable (no sensory/motor loss); Class IIa = marginally threatened (sensory loss, no motor); Class IIb = immediately threatened (motor deficit); Class III = irreversible (profound anesthesia, paralysis, fixed mottling)
Classic teaching: in pure embolism, contralateral leg has normal pulses (no underlying PAD). In thrombosis on atherosclerosis, contralateral often has diminished pulses too
CTA or duplex if time permits and not Class IIb/III; often proceed directly to OR for embolectomy in clear-cut cases; meniscus sign (convex filling defect) suggests embolism
Immediate anticoagulation (heparin); surgical embolectomy (Fogarty catheter) for Class IIa/IIb; fasciotomy if compartment syndrome; address embolic source (anticoagulation for AFib, echo)
All patients with arterial embolism should have echocardiogram to identify cardiac source; TEE more sensitive than TTE for left atrial thrombus and aortic arch disease
Large embolus lodging at aortic bifurcation causing bilateral acute limb ischemia; high mortality; requires emergent bilateral femoral embolectomy

learning_objectives: Distinguish embolism from thrombosis in acute limb ischemia
Know the 6 Ps of acute limb ischemia
Identify common embolic sources (AFib most common)
Understand Rutherford classification for treatment decisions
clinical_pearls: Sudden onset + no claudication history + normal contralateral pulses = embolism
Atrial fibrillation is the #1 source of peripheral embolism
Femoral bifurcation is the most common embolism site
Paralysis = muscle death = Class IIb/III = emergent intervention
All patients need echo to find cardiac source
Saddle embolus = bilateral leg ischemia = very sick patient
common_mistakes: Delaying intervention while waiting for imaging
Attempting revascularization in Class III (irreversible) limb
